fields.content:
Part 1

Learn the Names and Numbers of the Adult Orders

  • Primary
    		•  7
  • Concrete
    		•  8
  • Abstract
    		•  9
  • Formal
    		•  10
  • Systematic
    		•  11
  • Metasystematic         
    		• 12
fields.name: First

fields.content:
Part 2

Definitions

  • The next group has the definition of an order of hierarchical complexity on the front side.
  • The name and number of the order of hierarchical complexity are on the back side.
fields.name: Second

fields.content:
Part 3

Three Axioms of MHC

  1. Higher order actions are defined in terms of two or more different lower order actions.
    • This puts the actions into a hierarchical relationship:
      • From set theory, a set and a member of a set cannot be at the same level.
  2. The higher order actions organize or transform the two or more lower order ones:
    • This is how the actions are combined to form the new action
  3. The organization is not arbitrary,
    • This makes the organization match the real world.

Instructions

  • Rule: If axiom 1 is violated, then axioms 2 and 3 are also violated.
  • If axiom 2 is violated, then axiom 3 is violated.
  • There will be examples.
  • What order does the example meet?
  • What next order does the example fail to meet?
  • What axioms are violated and preclude the example from reflecting the next higher order?
  • What are the elements (Variables, relations, systems, relations among systems) used in the example?
fields.name: Third

fields.content:
Part 4

Identifying Sentences


  • In the following short groups of sentences, please determine the stage.
fields.name: Fourth

fields.content:
Part 5

Counselor Patient Vignettes


  • Read all five vignettes in the Counselor-Patient Interaction carefully.
  • Guess the stage of each vignette.
  • Guess the components of each vignette
    • What are the:
      • Variables
      • Relations
      • Systems
      • Relations among systems
  • The following 5 stories are set in another country. In each story, a Counselor tries to help a competent Patient to solve a given set of problems. The problems are serious. It is now time to choose a treatment to improve the situation. All the Counselors care for their Patients equally. All the Counselors highly recommend and provide the same basic treatments. But, the Counselors arrive at their choice of how to help in different ways. In every case, the problems worsen and those who are affected suffer. During a general review of these bad results, each Counselor's method of choosing a treatment was looked at. Below, the Counselors give accurate accounts of their usual talk with their Patients.
fields.name: Fifth

fields.question: Primary
fields.name: First-First

fields.question: Concrete
fields.name: First-Second

fields.question: Abstract
fields.name: First-Third

fields.question: Formal
fields.name: First-Fourth

fields.question: Systematic
fields.name: First-Fifth

fields.question: Metasystematic
fields.name: First-Sixth

fields.answer:
Primary
7
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • Paragraph long utterances are organized into stories.
  • These stories are matched to reality.
  • Addition, subtraction, multiplication, division.
  • Characterized by understanding own perspective or simple perspective of other person, but not together.
fields.name: Second-First

fields.answer:
Concrete
8
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • Simple logical deductions and time sequences are used to describe actual instances.
  • These instances are actual because they occur in past or present time.
  • They are composed of specific:
    • Things
    • IncidentsEvents
    • Actors
    • Actions
    • Places
  • Times in the context of the interaction between self and other.
fields.name: Second-Second

fields.answer:
Abstract
9
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • A label given a group of concrete things (e.g., the label “furniture” instead of listing objects “desks, chairs, tables”).
  • A label “feelings” instead of listing experiences of “happy, sad, mad”.
  • Classification words like “furniture,” “feelings,” “group,” “the law,” “teachers,” “politicians,” “polluters” are used.
  • Dualisms (e.g., best/worst, good/bad) and stereotypes result from using label variables.
fields.name: Second-Third

fields.answer:
Formal
10
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • These relational statements include:
    • Logical reasoning
    • Empirical problem solving
    • Understanding of events' cause and effect
  • Logical statements are built by coordinating variables.
  • Words occur like: "if... then".
fields.name: Second-Fourth

fields.answer:
Formal
10
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • Empirical support means something:
    • Supported by finding empirical relationships
    • Events are observable
    • Statements are verifiable with facts
  • Words occur like:
    • “in every case, it turned out the same”
    • “the reason is”
  • Words and sentences are linear and one-dimensional.
fields.name: Second-Fifth

fields.answer:
Systematic
11
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • Multiple relations are put into relation.
  • They must produce a sensible system of relations.
  • Words like functional and structural can be used to indicate such relations.
  • The concept structure may be used:
    • Does the structure of school help instill the qualities we want in future citizens?
fields.name: Second-Sixth

fields.answer:
Systematic
11
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • This order is “multivariate.” This means it coordinates multiple aspects of two or more relations:
    • “…relationships are built on trust and though we can’t always keep them, making promises is one way we build trust, so it’s generally better to make promises than not to make them.”
      • The importance of trust to relationships.
      • Building trust
      • the possibility that promises can be broken and
    • All are taken into account while formulating the conclusion that promises are desirable.
  • This is a system of relationships among the mentioned elements or variables.
fields.name: Second-Seventh

fields.answer:
Metasystematic
12
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • This order results from combining or comparing systems of relations.
  • Several systems are coordinated:
    • “contracts and promises are articulations of a unique human quality…
    • mutual trust, which coordinates human relations”:
      • Here, contracts and promises are seen as the instantiation of a broader principle coordinating human interactions.
  • Words occur like:
    • Autonomy
    • Parallelism
    • Heteronomy
    • Completeness
    • Incompleteness
  • Such words “build in” a coordination of systems.
fields.name: Second-Eighth

fields.answer:
Metasystematic
12
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • Institutional structures may be compared:
    • The military
      and
    • Summer camp
  • or of:
    • Prisons
      and
    • High schools
fields.name: Second-Ninth

fields.answer:
Metasystematic
12
fields.question:
What Order is defined here?

  • This order constructs multisystems out of disparate systems and perspectives.
  • The statement below is an example of this order. It is a participant’s perspective on what logic or evidence supports their personal view of Atheism.
    • The logic that truth statements ought to be based on observable or other derivable facts, not prophets, scripture, or other such dogma.
      • Compares empiricism and deductive reasoning with dogma to reach a conclusion.
fields.name: Second-Tenth

fields.answer:
Passes Primary 7

  • Story with logically ordered sequence events connected solidly to reality.
  • Some specified times, places, acts, actors.
  • Perspective of self.

Fails Concrete 8

  • Violates Axiom 1:
    • No new order is defined out of the Primary action.
    • Does not place story in the context of interaction between self and other.
fields.question:
• Task: Describe what the water is doing.
  • The water is filling the bathtub so I can take a bath
fields.name: Third-First

fields.answer:
Passes Primary 7

  • Uses simple arithmetic.

Fails Concrete 8

  • Violates Axiom 3:
    • Primary stage actions are organized, but the organization is arbitrary.
fields.question:
• Use distribution in the problem 2 x (3 +4)
  • 2+4x3
fields.name: Third-Second

fields.answer:
Passes Concrete 8

  • Can describe events in past and present that show interrelations.

Fails Abstract 9

  • Violates Axiom 1:
    • There is no new class defined in terms of generalization from, or classification of:
      • the concrete elements in the event
      • or any assertions to explain it
fields.question:
• Task: Describe how Tom got to see a movie he wanted to see.
  • Tom did his chore. He cleaned the house. Like the last time he did that, his parents gave Tom money for a movie he wanted to see.
fields.name: Third-Third

fields.answer:
Passes Abstract 9

  • Generalizes about classes of things and makes assertions based on generalization.

Fails Formal 10

  • Violates Axiom 1:
    • Abstract variables - All teachers, students who talk in class.
    • There is no logical or empirical evidence to support the generalized assertion using the abstract variables.
fields.question:
• Task: Describe what teachers do when students talk in class.
  • All teachers yell at students who talk in class.
fields.name: Third-Fourth

fields.answer:
Passes Abstract 9

  • Generalizes about classes of things and makes assertions based on generalization.

Fails Formal 10

  • Violates Axiom 2:
    • Abstract variables – cool kids use drugs, murdering people is bad.
    • There is no organization of the abstract variables.
    • The abstract variables are also arbitrary.
fields.question:
• Task: Describe who are likely to be involved in crime.
  • Cool kids use drugs, so murdering people in general is bad.
fields.name: Third-Fifth

fields.answer:
Passes Abstract 9

  • Generalizes about classes of things and makes assertions based on generalization.

Fails Formal 10

  • Violates Axiom 2:
    • Abstract variables – likes some comedies, salmon is the best fish.
    • There is no organization of the abstract variables.
    • The abstract variables are also arbitrary.
fields.question:
• Task: Describe what Alex likes.
  • Alex likes only some comedies, but also says that salmon is the best fish.
fields.name: Third-Sixth

fields.answer:
Passes Formal 10

  • Logical explanation that coordinates relations among abstract variables.

Fails Systematic 11

  • Violates Axiom 1:
    • Formal Variables – belief (“don't believe in God”), the view, sense-making (“doesn't make sense”).
    • Relations - If there was a God, it would make sense. It doesn't. There is no God.
  • The argument does not coordinate relations of formal variables to form a system of relations.
fields.question:
• Task: Defend atheism.
  • I don't believe in God, because there is no evidence or logic to support the view.
fields.name: Third-Seventh

fields.answer:
Passes Formal 10

  • Logical explanation that coordinates relations among abstract variables.

Fails Systematic 11

  • Violates Axiom 2:
    • Formal Variables – Cheating, understanding of material cannot be accurately assessed, classes based around discussion of material, promote student critical thinking.
    • Relations - When students cheat on tests, their understanding of material cannot be assessed. Classes based around student-teacher discussion promote students' critical thinking.
  • Two formal relations are presented but not related in any way.
  • The organization of the formal relations is arbitrary.
fields.question:
• Task: Discuss why students should not cheat on tests.
  • When students cheat on tests, their understanding of the material cannot be accurately assessed. Classes based around student-teacher discussion of the material promote students' critical thinking.
fields.name: Third-Eighth

fields.answer:
Passes Systematic 11

  • Multiple relations of formal variables are coordinated to form a coherent system of relations.

Fails Metasystematic 12

  • Violates Axiom 1:
    • Formal Variables - relationships, trust, promises.
    • Relations:
      1. Relationships are built on trust.
      2. Making promises builds trust.
      3. Promises cannot always be kept.
    • System – Promises' Identifies the role of making promises in building trusting relationships.
  • Forms one system of relations, rather than multiple systems.
fields.question:
• Task: Defend the value of making promises.
  • Relationships are built on trust and though we can’t always keep them, making promises is one way we build trust, so it’s generally better to make promises than not to make them.
fields.name: Third-Ninth

fields.answer:
Passes Metasystematic 12

  • Thus, it is essential that we have good educational systems that teach important values and support the institution of the family in its role as the primary source of upstanding citizens.
  • Coordination/principle: Essentialness of educational system supporting the role played by the family institution in society.
fields.question:
• Task: Task: Defend the importance of having good schools.
  • Children need to be taught values that will help them in our society. Outside of the family, schools are the main institutions for shaping values in children.
  • Thus, it is essential that we have good educational systems that teach important values and support the institution of the family in its role as the primary source of upstanding citizens.
fields.name: Third-Tenth

fields.answer:
Concrete

  • These sentences are concerned with specific:
    • People (Brown, Brown's friends, the patient)
    • Thing (this treatment).
  • Fails Abstract
    • Does not make any quantifications.
fields.question:
• Brown says that others who are friends use this treatment.
  • Brown instructs the patient to support the treatment.
fields.name: Fourth-First

fields.answer:
Abstract

  • These are categorical assertions:
    • Categorical assertions are declarations that do not include fact or logic.
    • They rely upon quantification (best, probably).
  • Fails Formal
    • No empirical evidence.
    • No relationships among abstract variables are formed.
fields.question:
• Kent says that the best counselors recommend this treatment.
  • Kent explains the method and tells the patient that it will probably work.
fields.name: Fourth-Second

fields.answer:
Formal

  • In this sentence, the abstract variables (treatment that has been studied, results of the study) are connected by the relation “and is shown”.
  • The sentence relates empirical evidence in a:
    • Logical.
    • Related context.
  • Fails Systematic
    • Only one formal relationship.
    • Does not coordinate multiple relationships to form system.
fields.question: • Bowers offers a treatment that has been studied and is shown to work well.
fields.name: Fourth-Third

fields.answer:
Systematic

  • These sentences contain a system of informing.
  • It includes asking questions, gaining patient’s perspective and understanding, not pushing, and encouraging comfortable choice-making.
  • Fails Metasystematic
    • Fails to coordinate the system of informing with the system of consenting.
fields.question:
• Young asks many questions in order to gain the patient’s perspective and understanding.
  • Young does not push the patient to accept any treatment but rather encourages the patient to make a choice that makes them feel comfortable.
fields.name: Fourth-Fourth

fields.answer:
Metasystematic

  • This sentence coordinates the systems of informing and consenting.
fields.question: • Heath asks the Patient to think about what they have both said about the alternatives and then think about choosing.
fields.name: Fourth-Fifth

fields.answer:
Concrete (8)

  • Variables - None
  • Relations - None
  • Systems - None
  • Relations among systems - None
fields.question: • Counselor Brown offers the Patient a treatment preferred by colleagues. Brown says that others who are friends use this treatment. A counselor who works next door is called in to tell the Patient again about the treatment. With great concern, Brown asks if the Patient would like to hear a third counselor explain the treatment. Brown's Patient is told that these people explain the treatment. Brown's Patient is told that these counselors had good results with that treatment. Brown instructs the Patient to support the treatment. Brown's Patient thinks seriously about what Brown has said. Feeling that Brown knows best, Brown's Patient prepares to undergo the treatment.
fields.name: Fifth-First

fields.answer:
Abstract (9)

  • Variables - Best counselors, recommended treatment, other methods that may work.
  • Relations - None
  • Systems - None
  • Relations among systems - None
fields.question: • Counselor Kents recently completed training on a treatment that was designed for the patient's problem. Kents says that the best counselors recommend this treatment. Kents explains the method and tells the patient that it will probably work for the patient. Kents also tells the patient about other methods that may work. The patient is asked if they have any questions. The patient does not have questions, and Kents ask them if they want to accept the recommended treatment. Feeling that Kents knows best, the patient prepares to undergo the treatment.
fields.name: Fifth-Second

fields.answer:
Formal (10)

  • Variables - Treatment, risks.
  • Relations - Any treatment will have risks, understand the treatment, outcome possibilities.
  • Systems - None
  • Relations among systems - None
fields.question: • Counselor Bowers offers a treatment that has been studied and is shown to work well. Bowers shares the fact that not everyone has had a positive outcome from the treatment. Bowers then reads a description of the treatment and its risks from a colleague's book. Bowers points out that any treatment will have risks. Bowers asks the patient if they understand the treatment and its outcome possibilities. After thinking carefully, Bowers' patient feels comfortable that Bowers is a capable clinician. Feeling that Bowers knows best, the patient prepares to undergo the treatment.
fields.name: Fifth-Third

fields.answer:
Systematic (11)

  • Variables - Aspects of treatment, alternatives, patient’s needs and concerns.
  • Relations - 1. Explaining all aspects of the treatment and describes at length the pros and cons of alternatives, including doing nothing. 2. Understanding needs and concerns to gain the patient's understanding and perspective.
  • Systems - Informing
  • Relations among systems - None
fields.question: • Counselor Young offers a treatment that best suits the needs of the patient. Young explains all aspects of the treatment and describes at length the pros and cons of alternatives, including doing nothing. Young seeks to understand the patients needs and concerns, and asks many questions in order to gain the patient’s perspective and understanding. Young does not push the patient to accept any treatment but rather encourages the patient to make a choice that makes them feel comfortable. The patient considers this. Feeling that Young knows best, the patient decides to undergo the treatment.
fields.name: Fifth-Fourth

fields.answer:
Metasystematic (12)

  • Variables - Alternatives, effects, side-effects, taking no action.
  • Relations - 1. Relates the effects and side-effects of each treatment including taking no action. 2. Asks the Patient questions about the treatments making sure the Patient understands. 3. Makes sure patient is comfortable making a decision with the information. 4. Asks the Patient to think carefully before choosing a treatment.
  • Systems - Informing, consenting.
  • Relations among systems - Asks the patient to coordinate what they have both said about the alternatives to make a decision on treatment.
fields.question: • Counselor Heath offers a treatment which performs relatively better than others. Heath relates the effects and side-effects of each treatment including taking no action. Then Heath asks the Patient questions about the treatments making sure the Patient understands. Heath asks if the Patient feels comfortable making a decision with the present information. Since the Patient is satisfied, Heath asks the Patient to think carefully before choosing a treatment. Heath asks the Patient to think about what they have both said about the alternatives and then think about choosing. Feeling that Heath knows best, Heath's Patient prepares to undergo the treatment.
fields.name: Fifth-Fifth
